conclusion: The problem involves analyzing whether a pedestrian can catch up with a bus based on their velocity-time graphs.
The velocity-time graph shows the pedestrian moving at a constant speed of 8 m/s (horizontal line) and the bus starting from rest and accelerating uniformly (diagonal line).
The two velocity curves intersect at t = 8 s, where both the pedestrian and the bus have a velocity of 8 m/s.
The bus's acceleration is calculated as a = Δv/Δt = 8 m/s ÷ 8 s = 1 m/s².
The initial separation between the pedestrian and the bus is 36 meters when the bus starts moving.
The position of the pedestrian over time is given by x₁(t) = -36 m + 8 m/s × t.
The position of the bus over time is given by x₂(t) = 0.5t² m.
To determine if they meet, solve -36 + 8t = 0.5t², which simplifies to 0.5t² - 8t + 36 = 0.
Using the quadratic formula, t = [8 ± √(64 - 72)]/1 = [8 ± √(-8)]/1, which results in no real solutions.
Since there are no real solutions, the pedestrian cannot catch up with the bus.
At t = 8 s, the bus reaches the same speed as the pedestrian (8 m/s), and after t = 8 s, the bus moves faster than the pedestrian.
By the time the pedestrian has closed some of the gap, the bus has accelerated to a speed that prevents the pedestrian from ever catching up.
The final conclusion is that the pedestrian will never catch up with the bus.
